text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: You just have never, everything you’ve had is all pill, pill, pill, pill, and your body’s figured it out, so. Patient: Okay. text: Patient: Then, why do I keep getting stuck? Doctor: Uh, because - Doctor: You know, we’re about ready to start, you know, a trial or a drug, uh, you know, so, Patient: So, you need that base, a current baseline? Doctor: Yeah, we wanna know where you are as we get started. Patient: And that’s understandable. Doctor: It’s your turn. I want you to do that for me. Patient: Yeah, no, you explained it, someone explained it that there’s - when chemo starts - it’ll be a blood test prior the chemo and a blood test after. And, uh, the leaving the timings out of it because I don’t really recall. And then, then roughly a week before the next cycle, there’ll be a blood test, then the chemo, and then, we’ll say within a week, I guess it’s another blood test. And that’s to keep an eye on, uh, all of these numbers? The blood cell or the white counts, etc.? Doctor: Yeah, I mean, so chemotherapy certainly can drop your blood counts and put you at risk for infection. Uh, so, we wanna make sure that, uh, how low is it to sort of - if you did have a fever, are we worried; are we not worried? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, and before we give you your next dose, we need to make sure that your counts have recovered (cell phone alert) Patient: Okay. (softly) Doctor: So, those are all, you know, the typical thing is with chemotherapy, you see myself or C__, you know, one day, and then we pick a day, the next day or the next day, to come in and get the chemotherapy. So, we’re really trying to do a safety evaluation that yes, it’s safe. Okay?

text: Family Member: But during that whole two years you don’t really know what’s going on because you can’t measure it accurately right?

DOC Because the hormone therapy is suppressing what’s there and killing off ninety nine percent of it, then maybe not that last one percent, maybe, maybe not, the radiation does that. So we’re giving you all that we got. Um hum. Um hum. We want it all. Okay. Um and leakage issue. I think he’s doing pretty good, but how long does that typically take?

DOC About another month or so. A lot of times people get better suddenly. Doctor: So if you’re seeing some improvement it will just continue to get better. Patient: Yeah I was tell G___ you know it when I’m not as active there’s no problem but uh I started work last night so I can definitely feel… Doctor: That’s very common. Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: You’re on the right track. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I bet within the month you’re maybe won’t need those pads anymore. Patient: Because the other thing too is uh I coach my daughters softball team so of course get that grade down, a bucket of ball (FAM Laughs) Doctor: So even a year or two from now it’s not gonna be – you don’t have as much resistance to outflow as you used to have. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: But it should be enough that you would be dry almost all the time. Patient: Mm, hmm.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years. Doctor: Yeah. Different people. I’m overstating it a little bit, but people are more tired. And uh, but people are more tired. And, and but if you exercise, it’s not as bad. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have the side effects of an increased heart attack risk. You don’t have, your bones don’t get soft, your muscles don’t go weak; you know exercise is the key here. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um, but um some guys have bad hot flashes. And some guys get depressed because their metabolism down. Um, but make no mistake, people keep working; they keep enjoying life; they’re just more tired. Family Member: Uh hum.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But my expectation is just to be very honest is that yes, there will be some degree of PSA reduction. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it may delay the need for hormone therapy for another six months from now with another twelve months from now. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: But I kind of do think that a hormone therapy is sort of inevitable for you. Um the other question that you asked was about using chemotherapy. I presume that you’re asking whether that was either given by itself or maybe in combination with hormone therapy like as a clumped – double therapy. And that we have also done - there have been trials to support that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And you know the clinical trials and also the clinical experience do suggest that when you combine standard hormone therapy with chemotherapy or standard hormone therapy with newer type of hormone therapy called (novel) Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. But but again, I don’t want you to go into that thinking that it’s going to increase the chance of a cure. The cure rate is still you know pretty close to zero percent and that it increases the length of time that that systemic therapy works. Patient: Okay. And see, that that that’s my concern at this point. Um you know um you think in terms of the reason I keep pushing hormonal so far back is because I know that’s a proven method - Doctor: Yeah. It is -

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Ummm, they compare it to the CAT scan. The CAT scan says there maybe new but more intense. Uh, but bone scans trump CAT scans. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Umm, so, we could technically say that that’s stable. Um. They comment more about your jaw this time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: They’re saying that it’s more intense. Uh, and they’re saying this could be more cancer then, you know, dental disease. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. It’s hard to say that because basically a bone scan is just about inflammation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so, if you had dental work or there’s inflammation from troubles related to the Xgeva. That would light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, if it’s the cancer that’s really causing it, then that, that would cause it to light up. Patient: Okay.

text: Family Member: I see. Doctor: Abiraterone is probably what I would prefer. Although for you, the downsides of it is potentially, you know, fluid retention. Huh, there is a lot of fatigue related to it. Huh, huh, we have to watch your blood tests a little bit. Huh, about seventy-five percent, three out of four people, their PSA is going to drop on it. Huh, the average person’s on it for about fifteen months, then the cancer figures it out, and we have to look at maybe moving to something else. We don’t change therapy based on PSA. We base it on how you’re feeling and whether your scans show more cancer than what we saw today. Okay? Patient: Now, what would you recommend right now? Doctor: Yeah. I, I like the abiraterone but we’ll have to check to sort of see what the cost is to you. The other one doesn’t need prednisone. It makes people a little bit more frail so I’m a little bit more worried about that one in you. Huh, you know, we don’t have right offhand a clinical trial that I can think about. Our first study with abiraterone, you have to have a mutation which you don’t have. So we would just be able to give you abiraterone. Our enzalutamide plus new drug first-line study is on hold right now. Huh, the two other studies that we have all require that you have had abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, so usually after one of these drugs if your cancer is getting worse more options from a clinical trial perspective open up. Huh, we just finished our study of radiation and a vaccine. We don’t know if that has any activity or working yet to see whether or not, huh, that would be a standard option. Huh, you aren’t eligible, so right now, it would be the abiraterone that we would head towards. So what I typically do is send an email to our pharmacy saying can you price this out, then speak to you about whether you can afford it or not afford it, and then, huh, they work on sort of the patient assistance program, if you need it. Huh, if you don’t need it or you get one of those things, then they can provide the drug. Huh, we might have you come in and meet with that pharmacist or one of the nurse practitioners that I work with, huh, to sort of just re-go over what you may feel with starting the new drug, or that if, again, we just can’t get it for you, we can try the other one, or we would think maybe even going to the radium, which is a liquid radiation drug, which is given here in the clinic. Usually that’s what we go to next. Patient: That’s what I had before but they, radia, huh- Doctor: Rad. Patient: She injected me with something. Family Member: No. No. Doctor: You’ll continue on your hormone shots every three months for the rest of your life. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so I’ll set that visit up for sure. Huh, and then, huh, hopefully within the next couple of weeks we’ll be able to figure out where you are and you can get started on the abiraterone. Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them?

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So what they found is if you give a little bit of prednisone, which is also kind of a hormone, it balances that out. Uh, so we just give a once-a-day low dose, and that seems to be enough to keep the potassium normal. But some people don’t like prednisone. It makes them feel weird. It makes them gain weight. It makes them eat more. Patient: Oh. (Laughter) Doctor: And so, uh, the standard dose was twice a day. We found that if we just give it once a day, it’s enough to counterbalance the thing. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, so I think either one would be fine. You know? I think choosing either one would be fine. But I think that’s what I would do next is- now, the way I do that is, the other side effect of these drugs are they’re very expensive. So what we do is, uh, we have a whole group here whose job is, if we decide we’re going to do one or the other, I will call them today, and say, “I want to put you on X.” Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They will go and look at your insurance. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Figure out what X is going to cost. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: What’s the best pharmacy to get it from?

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. (pause) Patient: Okay. So, uh, if, so I guess the, the question is stay on this, this um, a clinic, stay in the clinical trial. Let’s see what happens the next, you know, three months from now. Doctor: Right. Patient: Is one option. And what other options are there? Doctor: Yeah. So, other options would be then we would stop this therapy and say that hey, you know, all the data says it’s gotten worse. Um, and, then we would look at other treatments. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: They’ve had Radium. You’ve got Abiraterone. You’ve got Enzalutamide. So, we would look at possibly chemotherapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, off, uh, clinical studies, chemotherapy would be, uh, the reasonable next step --- Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We’ve got Taxotere, uh, would be what we would use. Patient: Okay.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
